p: Consistent with this, it has been demonstrated that lower levels of n-3 fatty acids are associated with increased body weight in children, but there is no clear evidence that n-3 supplementation has an impact on adiposity or BMI [ 44]. A recent double-blind trial evaluated the effect of daily fish oil supplementation (1.2 g of n-3 LCPUFAs) vs. placebo (sunflower oil) in a cohort of 366 obese adolescents following a hypocaloric diet: no difference in body weight, HOMA index, and insulin level changes were found between the two groups [ 45]. Another randomized double-blind trial studied the effects of 15 weeks of supplementation of n-3 fatty acids vs. placebo (rapeseed oil) in 423 children aged 8â€“9 years old, measuring body weight and Physical Activity (PA). No significant difference in neither PA nor BMI between the two groups was found [ 46].
